conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same point and move in the same direction. Their velocities over time are plotted in a graph.
The graph is a velocity-time graph with time (t) on the x-axis and velocity (v) on the y-axis. There are two lines, one for particle A and one for particle B.
Particle A starts from rest, its velocity increases to 2v₀ at t=t₀, decreases to zero at t=2t₀, and becomes negative, reaching -v₀ at t=3t₀.
Particle B starts from rest, reaches a velocity of v₀ at t=3t₀, maintains v₀ until t=5t₀, and decreases to zero at t=6t₀.
The distance between the particles is the difference in their positions, s(t) = s_A(t) - s_B(t).

premise: The distance between them at any time t is s(t) = s_A(t) - s_B(t).
conclusion: To find when they are farthest apart, find the maximum value of s(t), which occurs when ds/dt = 0.
To find when s(t) is maximum, find when v_A - v_B = 0, meaning their velocities are equal.
The graph shows that v_A and v_B intersect at some point.

premise: The relative distance is the integral of (v_A - v_B) dt from t=0 to t.
conclusion: s(t) = ∫(v_A - v_B) dt from 0 to t.

premise: To find the maximum of s(t), take its derivative and set it to zero: ds/dt = v_A - v_B = 0.

conclusion: The intersection of v_A and v_B occurs around t=2t₀.

premise: The graph shows the intersection of v_A and v_B.
conclusion: The farthest distance occurs at the red dot between 2t₀ and 3t₀.
